citation.article-title: Zobellia galactanovorans gen. nov., sp. nov., a marine species of Flavobacteriaceae isolated from a red alga, and classification of [Cytophaga] uliginosa (ZoBell and Upham 1944) Reichenbach 1989 as Zobellia uliginosa gen. nov., comb. nov.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Zobellia galactanovorans sp. nov.
Zobellia galactanovorans (ga.lac.ta.no.vo'rans. M.L. n. galactan polygalactose; L. v. vorare to devour; M.L. fem. adj. galactanovorans galactan-devouring)
(basonym 'Cytophaga drobachiensis' Barbeyron et al. 1998) Colonies on ZoBell 2216E agar plate are yellow and spread rapidly on the surface of the plate.
Cells are rods (0.3-0.4 by 3.0-8.0 μm), with rounded ends and are non-motile in liquid phase.
On solid surfaces, gliding motility is easily observed.
i-Carrageenan is liquefied within 1 week at room temperature.
Gelatin and DNA are also hydrolysed.
Starch is hydrolysed in starch agar and starch Phytagel plates.
Cells are positive for catalase, cytochrome-c oxidase, β-glucosidase (aesculin test) and β-galactosidase activities (o- and p-nitrophenyl-β-D-galactoside tests).
Cells do not produce H#S nor indole from tryptophan.
Do not possess urease or arginine dihydrolase.

D-Glucose, L-arabinose, D-mannose, D-mannitol, L-rhamnose, L-fucose, maltose, N-acetylglucosamine, D/L-glycerol phosphate or L-serine can serve as the sole carbon source, but not D-lyxose, dtagatose, α-ketobutyric acid, L-threonine, urocanic acid, gluconate, 2-keto-gluconate, caprate, adipate, malate, citrate or phenyl acetate.
Acid production is observed from D-glucose, sucrose, maltose, L-arabinose, rhamnose, D-fructose, D-galactose, D-mannose, D-mannitol and starch, but not from D-sorbitol or glycerol.
The DNA G+C content is 43 mol%.
The type strain is Zobellia galactanovorans DsijT, isolated from pieces of the red alga Delesseria sanguinea (Huds.) Lamour.
Strain DsijT has been deposited in the DSMZ and in the Institut Pasteur Collection under the accession numbers DSM 12802T and CIP 106680T, respectively.
